title: What are your regrets from high school? - Quora

response.answer_text: 1. Choosing a relationship over your friends.  Trust me: I did this, and it is one of the biggest regrets of my life. I know that a first or new relationship is exciting and you want to be with your S.O. all the time. I get it! But please try to refrain from revolving your life around them. Your friends are so important and this is one of the times of your life where you will really be able to be with them a lot. Don’t waste it. 2. Acting like you didn’t like someone just to make things “work.”  Why be in a friends with benefits relationship if you really like the guy more than that? Why act like you’re fine with being casual if you’re not? Stop settling! It will lead to heartbreak and trust issues that you will carry for years. 3. Not standing up for the underdog.  I know this sounds cliche and boring, but it’s true. It’s so hard to find high school students who stand up for the underdogs and the bullied kids. Be that person, because you’re better than being a bully. Years later, when you think about how mean people in school were to one person, you’re going to feel horribly guilty. 4. Choosing not to do something because you were worried about what other people thought.  I know that you’re bombarded with messages like “Be yourself!” and “Stop caring what others think!” After a while it’s like, “Okay, but how?” or it just gets frustrating. It’s easy to spread this message, but it’s not easy to follow it. But when I think back to high school, I think of all the things I DIDN’T do because I was worried I would look like a “nerd.” I’m disappointed in myself even now. 5. Not saving money.  I worked all throughout high school, but you wouldn’t know it because I didn’t save any of that money. I spent it on stupid things like clothes from Pac Sun that I wore once and food I didn’t even need. Do you know how much you’ll have for college if you save during high school? 6. Wearing things or doing things you were uncomfortable with just to be cool.  Yes, I’m talking about peer pressure, and yes, I realize you all are sick of hearing about it. But it’s important to discuss, so we’re going to. Real talk: when I was in high school, the “cool” older kids all smoked cigarettes. I wanted to be cool, so I smoked. I only did it socially, but…. I didn’t like it. And I did it. Why? It was so stupid. 7. Fighting with your parents and telling them you hate them.  I know parents are annoying and restrictive and are trying to ruin your life. I had such strict parents and I really get how infuriating and upsetting it can be. During high school, I fought with my parents constantly. I told them I hated them all the time. I pushed them away. I refused to get to know them. Now my parents are seriously my best friends and I feel really bad about how hard I made things back then. Just don’t say things you’ll regret, okay? 8. Letting a friendship fall apart because you didn’t want to seem like you cared.  When I was in high school, I got in a huge fight with one of my best friends. I was devastated, but I thought that if I showed how much I cared, I would look like a loser. So instead I acted like I didn’t care and refused to try to patch things up. I STILL miss that best friend, guys. And things never, ever went back to the way they were. If you care about someone, it’s okay to show it. I promise. 9. Choosing a guy over a friend and backstabbing her.  Not. Okay. This happened to me and it sucked. It’s mean. The thing with the guy probably won’t last, but your friend will never talk to you again, probably. Just don’t do it because I promise it’s not worth it. 10. Not telling a friend you were angry with her because you didn’t want to start a fight.  This was literally my life in high school. I would get mad at friends for legitimate reasons, then refuse to confront them because I was terrified of confrontation. The result? I developed emotional and anger issues and it took years to be able to speak up for myself. Also, it made me bitter. I know it’s hard to tell a friend if you’re angry, but you should, because it will prevent a lot of problems. 11. Not paying attention to grades at all.  Yeah, school sucks and homework is boring. While there are plenty of students who DO try a lot, there are also plenty who don’t. I was an okay student with Bs and As, but I didn’t try as hard as I should have. I regret that, and you might too. 12. Following the path you thought you had to follow.  Maybe your parents had an idea of what they wanted to do, and you’re doing it just to live up to their expectations. Maybe you had a plan and even though your mind is changing, you don’t want to abandon it. Maybe you absolutely hate school but you’re applying to college because it’s normal and expected in our society. But you know what? You should take your own path and do what feels right for you. And only you will know what that is. 13. Spending all your time trying to please people.  I did this a lot. I wanted to make my parents happy. I wanted to make my boyfriend happy. I wanted to make my friends happy. My teachers, my guidance counselor, my family, etc. I never focused on making ME happy. Don’t do this. 14. Acting super, super shy.  I was painfully shy in high school. I know how incredibly difficult it is to NOT be shy when you are. But please try. I regret so much of that shyness. It held me back from so much. 15. Obsessing over having sex or kissing someone.  If you spend 99 percent of your time wondering who your first kiss will be or wondering if you’re weird for never having been in relationship or obsessing over your first time, stop. There is more to life than this stuff. 16. Choosing your future based on a guy.  My biggest regret in life is not going away to college because my high school boyfriend didn’t want me to. My other biggest regret is not studying abroad because he didn’t want me to. We broke up shortly after. GUYS I WISH I DIDN’T DO THIS. I can’t even express how much I regret this. Please, please, please, consider ONLY you when making future plans like these. 17. Sticking to just one group of friends.  A lot of high schoolers make a little group of friends and stick to those friends. Expand your group! I didn’t do that in high school, but I do it now, and it’s great. I have a few separate groups of friends and it’s so much better than having just one. 18. Refusing to do things alone.  Learn how to be independent! I promise it will make life so much better. 19. Choosing to do drugs.  Is this GIF funny? Yeah. Are drugs? No. I don’t want to sound like your mom, but drugs suck. I’m not talking about weed or cigarettes, I’m talking about the harder stuff that ruins lives. Starting young is asking for an addiction you will have a serious problem shaking. Drugs are the worst. I have watched so many promising lives get destroyed by drugs. It’s heartbreaking. It’s not a joke. Please don’t do them. 20. Not showing or telling your crush how you feel.  Yeah, I know, you’re told this all the time. But try it. Seriously.

I have to go anonymous on this because it could cause problems for people, sorry. I recently was dragged to my 25th high school reunion by my best friend growing up. Although I had a great time in high school (it really was some of the best years of my life), I had never really felt the need to go to one of our reunions. Everyone who I wanted to keep in touch with, I still kept in touch with, and I never really cared much about finding out what happened to so and so. The 25th reunion was a special one, or so my friend kept insisting, so I agreed to go. Surprisingly, it was a blast! So many faces that I hadn’t seen in a quarter century. My high school is huge (I mean really huge) and we had a great turnout (hundreds of grads), so it really was fun reconnecting. In particular, it was fun reconnecting with one specific girl, let’s call her Jane. Jane happened to be a girl I had worshiped for my last 3 years of high school. We ran in adjacent circles — me with smart kids and smart jocks, her with dumb jocks and smart jocks — and I just thought she was the bees knees. Jane wasn’t the prettiest girl in school, but she was probably top 10 in my estimation. She wasn’t the smartest girl in school, but she had a sprinkling of honors classes. I had girlfriends in high school, but I always liked Jane better than any of them. Jane was a cheerleader (of course) and she was always dating football players. She never knew about my affection and I never admitted it, even to my closest friends — I was too chicken to say anything to her about it as I figured she was out of my league. We graduated after having said maybe 10 words to each other and went our separate ways. Over time, I loved and lost and eventually happily married and started a family. I am truly content and happy. As it happens, Jane sought me out at the reunion — much to my surprise. After not having spoken to each other in high school, we talked for quite some time at the reunion. It turns out that Jane wasn’t going to come to the reunion until she found out I was coming (say what?). She had always wondered what happened to the “smartest kid in our school” and wanted to see me. Jane said she had always liked me in high school, but it always seemed like one of us was dating someone else. Worse yet, during the times when we weren’t both dating, she was hoping I would approach her, but I never did. Even worse yet, Jane never talked to me in high school because she thought I wouldn’t like her because I would think she was too dumb. I never talked to Jane in high school because I was intimidated by how pretty she was. Great googly moogly, what a moron I was back then. **** Update Due to quora’s new handling of anonymous posts, I can no longer reply to any comments. Here are answers to a couple of common questions: Jane and I have no plans to pursue a relationship. While I am kicking myself at missing out on what could have been a great life experience, I am happily married with kids and this event has largely just been a wistful look back in time.Back then, it was highly rare for girls to approach boys. It just didn’t happen in that era, so the burden was not shared equally. I accept 100% of the blame for my inadequacy of courage.
